content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very cool! The description is very well explained. Is fun and not very hard.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Is easy to understand the description and looks like a fun thing to code

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: An easy and fun challenge that doesn't involve too much math. 
The instruction is especially clear on the direction, positive / negative, assumed so there should be little confusion.

Constraints section
* Please remove the first constraint (regarding the variables being integers), as it merely repeats what has already been stated in the Input section.
* Please move the last constraint to the Goal section, as it is explanation of the directions instead of a constraint.

Thanks.

I just marked this as ready after a few minor changes:
[[n]] input is now on line 2 instead of after [[x]] and [[y]].
Clarified phrasing in statement.
Added integer constraints.
Added reverse mode.

This will be good one for reverse type, i suggest you include it.
Also, please add integer constraints
Great clash !

I like this for clash, if you wanted to make a puzzle out of it though I think you can also provide directions such as NE, NW, SE, SW. Why even stop there, you can have coordinates such as N by NE, which is supposed to represent a direction between N and NE on the compass and x, y would be decimals.
I'm starting to think this would be better suited to a classic puzzle because it's probably too long for a Clash of Code problem.
Delete one https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/16317ca0d4c8cf7912bc558719dde7f2c05f1
Oops my bad, must have been an internet hiccup. Deleted the other one.
Nah, it's not that long, even for fastest, people can come up with the solution pretty quickly. It's straightforward and simple, there's potential for the shortest mode too. I like this.
I was originally going to do that because I'm a geography (and nautical history) nerd, but I decided to keep it super basic for the purpose of a Clash puzzle.

I think the info you would get in reverse mode could be quite obscure, especially for someone who isn't familiar with how a compass works. I suppose it's all right to have a few challenging ones.

The coordinates and distances don't have to be integers (as opposed to floats), but they can be for simplicity's sake. How do I add that constraint? Just state it under the "Constraints" section? Or do you mean that the outputs must be integers if the inputs are?

Done, thanks.

If I specify in the Input section which are positive integers too, is there any information I should include in the Constraints section? I don't think the magnitude of any of the numbers matters beyond language limitations, but it doesn't feel right leaving it empty.

It can be left empty if there are really no constraints.
Think of what information would help you decide, during coding as a player:
* whether to put in additional code to deal with a certain case, or
* whether to simplify some code because a case will never happen?
One common constraint (not applicable to your case) is that "all inputs are in lowercase", which means the player can safely exclude any code to convert the input to lowercase first before doing anything.

In that case I think I'll leave it empty.
The numbers don't have constraints beyond some being positive, and I already explained how the [[dir]] input works in the statement, so it would be redundant to constrain it to those four characters.

Yes, add in constraints section please. For example, if numbers can be around100000 and above - using regular int type can give you an overflow in some languages, etc, people need to plan accordingly.
Well, up to you, it's hard for me to imagine people not knowing what NSWE represents, but not arguing. thanks for the clash

I added reverse mode after making the inputs a bit clearer.

As was discussed on 5DN1L's comment, there aren't any constraints beyond language limitations that aren't already specified elsewhere, and I feel it's up to the player to know their language. My test cases don't use numbers greater than 1000 so that shouldn't cause an overflow unless someone uses 8 bit integers for some reason.

Because of "Fastest" category, i'd think the constraints are needed, because the contestant needs to plan his solution accordingly. May be you're using big integers (with hundreds of digits)?
But it might not be too crucial
